quoteFirst: Too well had the assassin done his work! The President never spoke, or recovered consciousness. He was carried from the theatre to a house near at hand, where, at
quoteLast: the next morning, he expired, with his mourning friends around him.
title: The Backwoods Boy; or, The Boyhood and Manhood of Abraham Lincoln
author: Alger, Horatio, Jr., 1832-1899

quoteFirst: About dawn his pulse began to fail. A little later, "a look of unspeakable peace came over his worn features"(15), and at
quoteLast: on the morning of the fifteenth of April, he died.
title: Lincoln; An Account of his Personal Life, Especially of its Springs of Action as Revealed and Deepened by the Ordeal of War
author: Stephenson, Nathaniel W. (Nathaniel Wright), 1867-1935

quoteFirst: Dennison, and the others arranged along at his left, and the surgeons were sitting upon the side and foot of the bed, holding the President’s hands, and with their watches observing the slow declension of the pulse, and watching the faint ebb of that noble spirit. Such was the solemn stillness for the duration of five minutes that the ticking of many watches could be heard in the room. At
quoteLast: , A. M., the soul of Abraham Lincoln fled from its earthly tabernacle “to that bourne from which no traveler returns.” As he drew his last breath the Rev. Dr. Gurley addressed the Throne of Grace with a fervent prayer for his heart-broken family and his mourning country.
title: Pictorial history of the war for the Union, volume 2 (of 2)
author: Stephens, Ann S. (Ann Sophia), 1810-1886

quoteFirst: Too well had the assassin done his work! The President never spoke, or recovered consciousness. He was carried from the theatre to a house near at hand, where, at
quoteLast: the next morning, he expired, with his mourning friends around him.
title: The Backwoods Boy; or, The Boyhood and Manhood of Abraham Lincoln
author: Alger, Horatio, Jr., 1832-1899

quoteFirst: On the evening of April 14, 1865, while seated in a box at Ford's Theatre, witnessing the play, "Our American Cousin," he was shot by an actor, J. Wilkes Booth, and at
quoteLast: on the morning of the 15th his life ended. His body was embalmed and taken, in funeral procession, from Washington through Baltimore, Harrisburg, Philadelphia, New York, Albany, Buffalo, Cleveland, and Chicago to Springfield, and was buried on May 4th at Oak Ridge Cemetery.
title:
Great Men and Famous Women. Vol. 4
A series of pen and pencil sketches of the lives of more than 200 of the most prominent personages in History
author: Horne, Charles F. (Charles Francis), 1870-1942 [Editor]

quoteFirst: But for his powerful physique and his abundant vitality, it would have brought instant death. He never recovered consciousness, but lingered through the night and died at
quoteLast: in the morning. Dr. Gurley, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, which the President attended, was kneeling in prayer by his bedside; Surgeon-General Barnes, of the army, had his finger upon the President's pulse; Robert Lincoln, Senator Sumner, and one of the assistant secretaries leaned upon the foot of the bed.
title: Abraham Lincoln
author: Curtis, William Eleroy, 1850-1911

quoteFirst: But for his powerful physique and his abundant vitality, it would have brought instant death. He never recovered consciousness, but lingered through the night and died at
quoteLast: in the morning. Dr. Gurley, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, which the President attended, was kneeling in prayer by his bedside; Surgeon-General Barnes, of the army, had his finger upon the President's pulse; Robert Lincoln, Senator Sumner, and one of the assistant secretaries leaned upon the foot of the bed.
title: Abraham Lincoln
author: Curtis, William Eleroy, 1850-1911

quoteFirst: The bleeding President was carried to a house across the street, No. 516, where he died at
quoteLast: the next morning. The body was taken to the White House and, after lying in state in the East Room and at the Capitol, left Washington on the 21st of April, stopping at various places en route, and finally arriving at Springfield on the 3rd of May.
title: Lincoln's Birthday
author: Schauffler, Robert Haven, 1879-1964 [Editor]
